title: Jeremiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 14.

questions.question: What was Jeremiah's message concerning in Jeremiah 14:1?
options: The dearth
The flood
The exile
The temple building
questions.correctAnswer: The dearth
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:1 states that the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah concerning the dearth.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 14:2, what is the condition of Judah's gates?
options: They languish and are black unto the ground
They are open and bright
They are fortified and strong
They are decorated with gold
questions.correctAnswer: They languish and are black unto the ground
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:2 describes Judah's gates as languishing and black unto the ground.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14:3, why did the nobles' little ones return with their vessels empty?
options: They found no water in the pits
They were stopped by enemies
They lost the vessels
The vessels were broken
questions.correctAnswer: They found no water in the pits
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:3 states the little ones came to the pits but found no water and returned with empty vessels.

questions.question: What caused the plowmen to be ashamed according to Jeremiah 14:4?
options: Because the ground was chapt due to no rain
Because they lost their oxen
Because they sowed the wrong seeds
Because their tools were broken
questions.correctAnswer: Because the ground was chapt due to no rain
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:4 explains that the ground was chapt for there was no rain, causing the plowmen to be ashamed.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 14:5, what happened to the hind in the field?
options: It calved and forsook the field because there was no grass
It died from thirst
It was caught by hunters
It stayed and grazed peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: It calved and forsook the field because there was no grass
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:5 states that the hind calved in the field and forsook it due to lack of grass.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14:6, what did the wild asses do in the high places?
options: They snuffed up the wind like dragons
They drank from the streams
They rested under trees
They fled to the valleys
questions.correctAnswer: They snuffed up the wind like dragons
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:6 describes the wild asses standing in high places, snuffing up the wind like dragons.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 14:7 says that the people have no iniquities or sins against God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:7 admits that their iniquities testify against them and that they have sinned against God.

questions.question: Who is called the 'hope of Israel' in Jeremiah 14:8?
options: The LORD
Jeremiah
The king of Judah
The priests
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:8 calls the LORD the hope and saviour of Israel in time of trouble.

questions.question: What does the LORD say about the people's wandering in Jeremiah 14:10?
options: They have loved to wander and not refrained their feet
They have remained faithful
They have returned to Him
They have built altars
questions.correctAnswer: They have loved to wander and not refrained their feet
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:10 states that the people have loved to wander and not refrained their feet, causing the LORD not to accept them.

questions.question: True or False: In Jeremiah 14:11, God tells Jeremiah to pray for the people’s good.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:11 states that the LORD told Jeremiah not to pray for the people for their good.

questions.question: What will God not accept when the people fast, according to Jeremiah 14:12?
options: Their cry and burnt offerings
Their prayers and songs
Their alms and sacrifices
Their vows and tithes
questions.correctAnswer: Their cry and burnt offerings
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:12 says God will not hear their cry nor accept burnt offerings and oblations when they fast.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 14:14, what do false prophets prophesy?
options: False visions and divinations
True and comforting words
Judgments and warnings
Historical events
questions.correctAnswer: False visions and divinations
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:14 explains that false prophets prophesy lies, false visions, and divinations not commanded by God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 14:17 says, 'Let mine eyes run down with tears ______ and day, and let them not cease.'
options: night
morning
forever
always
questions.correctAnswer: night
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:17 says, 'Let mine eyes run down with tears night and day, and let them not cease.'

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 14:19 expresses a plea asking if God has utterly rejected Judah.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:19 questions if God has utterly rejected Judah and laments the lack of healing.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 14:22, what do the people say about rain and the heavens?
options: No one among the Gentiles can cause rain or give showers, only the LORD can
The Gentiles can cause rain and showers
The heavens can give showers without the LORD
Rain comes only by chance
questions.correctAnswer: No one among the Gentiles can cause rain or give showers, only the LORD can
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:22 states that no one among the Gentiles can cause rain or give showers, but the LORD our God can.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Jeremiah 14, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in difficult times?
options: Trust God as the hope and savior in times of trouble
Trust your own strength to overcome trials
Ignore the difficulties and pretend all is well
Rely on human wisdom to find peace
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God as the hope and savior in times of trouble
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:8 calls the LORD the hope of Israel and savior in times of trouble, encouraging believers to trust God even when He seems distant. This is reinforced by verses 9 and 22 which affirm God’s presence and power over creation.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 14 teach us about humility and confession before God when facing consequences of sin?
options: Confess our wickedness and recognize our sins
Blame others for our problems
Ignore sin and hope it goes away
Justify our actions to avoid guilt
questions.correctAnswer: Confess our wickedness and recognize our sins
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:7 and 20 show the people confessing their many sins and iniquities, acknowledging their guilt before God which is a model for humility and repentance. This confession is essential for seeking God's help.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because God seems silent during hardship. According to Jeremiah 14, what encouragement can you give about God's presence?
options: God is in the midst of His people and they are called by His name
God has abandoned us completely
We should rely only on ourselves
God is unaware of our troubles
questions.correctAnswer: God is in the midst of His people and they are called by His name
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:9 affirms that although God may seem astonished, He is still in the midst of His people, and they bear His name. This encourages believers to trust in God's nearness despite appearances.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 14 teach about prayer and intercession when people persist in sin?
options: God may instruct not to pray for people who refuse to repent
Prayer always guarantees immediate blessings
Prayer is unnecessary in times of judgment
Prayer can be replaced by sacrifices alone
questions.correctAnswer: God may instruct not to pray for people who refuse to repent
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:11 records God's command to Jeremiah not to pray for the people’s good because of their persistent sin, emphasizing that prayer must be accompanied by repentance to be effective (verses 10,12).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 14 warn about false prophets and the importance of discerning truth?
options: False prophets prophesy lies and give false peace
All prophets are always true and trustworthy
False prophets can be ignored without consequence
Prophecy is not important to believers
questions.correctAnswer: False prophets prophesy lies and give false peace
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:14-15 highlights that some prophets speak lies in God's name, promising peace when disaster is coming. Believers must discern true prophecy to avoid deception.

questions.question: A believer faces famine and suffering. What biblical truth from Jeremiah 14 encourages perseverance and faith in God’s sovereignty?
options: God controls the rain and heavens and is sovereign over all
Famine is random and unrelated to sin or God’s will
Human effort alone can end suffering
Ignore God during suffering
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the rain and heavens and is sovereign over all
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:22 reminds believers that God is the one who makes the heavens and causes rain and showers, encouraging faith in His sovereign control even during hardships.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 14 illustrate the importance of honesty and integrity in acknowledging our spiritual state?
options: The people openly acknowledge their sin and suffering
They deny any wrongdoing and blame others
They hide their problems from God
They pretend all is well
questions.correctAnswer: The people openly acknowledge their sin and suffering
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:19-20 show the people honestly confessing their wickedness and questioning God, demonstrating integrity and transparency in their relationship with Him.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 14, when the people fast and offer sacrifices without repentance, God will accept their worship.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:12 clearly states that God will not hear their cry nor accept burnt offerings and oblations if their hearts remain unrepentant, showing that genuine repentance is necessary for worship to be accepted.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 14 describes God's heart as unaffected by the suffering of His people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:17 depicts Jeremiah's eyes running down with tears day and night because of the great breach and grievous blow to the virgin daughter of God's people, showing God's deep compassion reflected through His prophet.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Jeremiah 14:4, the plowmen were ashamed and covered their heads because the ground was ________.
options: chapt
wet
fertile
frozen
questions.correctAnswer: chapt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:4 states the ground was chapt (dried up) due to no rain, causing shame among the plowmen who covered their heads, illustrating the visible effects of drought and judgment.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 14 teach about the consequences of persistent disobedience to God?
options: God will visit their sins and not accept them
God will overlook their disobedience
Disobedience has no real consequences
God rewards disobedience with blessings
questions.correctAnswer: God will visit their sins and not accept them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:10 explains that because the people love to wander and have not restrained their feet, the LORD will not accept them and will remember their iniquity and visit their sins.

questions.question: What biblical principle about stewardship and dependence on God is shown through the lack of water in Jeremiah 14?
options: God controls natural resources and we must depend on Him
Water shortages are unrelated to God’s will
We should hoard resources selfishly
Human wisdom can solve all problems
questions.correctAnswer: God controls natural resources and we must depend on Him
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:3-4 describe how the people searched for water but found none, showing dependence on God’s provision, who controls rain and drought as affirmed in verse 22.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 14 encourage believers to maintain faith and wait on God during trials?
options: We should wait upon the LORD because He made all things
Give up hope and rely on human strength
Act impulsively without seeking God
Ignore prayer and wait silently
questions.correctAnswer: We should wait upon the LORD because He made all things
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:22 emphasizes waiting on the LORD since He is the creator of heaven and earth, encouraging patient trust even in difficult times.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14, what does the imagery of wild asses standing in the high places and snuffing the wind teach about the effects of spiritual and physical drought?
options: It shows desperation and weakness due to lack of sustenance
It depicts strength and abundance
It encourages self-reliance
It suggests ignoring the problem
questions.correctAnswer: It shows desperation and weakness due to lack of sustenance
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:6 uses this imagery to portray the failing eyes and desperation of the wild asses due to no grass, symbolizing the distress caused by drought and judgment.

questions.question: What lesson about intercession and obedience is shown when God tells Jeremiah not to pray for the people’s good?
options: Intercession requires a repentant heart from those prayed for
Prayer can force God to change His mind
One should never stop praying regardless of circumstances
God is indifferent to prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Intercession requires a repentant heart from those prayed for
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:11-12 shows that God refuses to accept prayers or fasting from unrepentant people, indicating intercession is effective only when accompanied by genuine repentance.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 14.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14:2, what is the condition of the gates of Judah as described during the time of dearth?
options: They languish and are black unto the ground
They are fortified and strong
They are open and welcoming
They are guarded by soldiers
questions.correctAnswer: They languish and are black unto the ground
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:2 states that Judah mourns and the gates languish, being black unto the ground, symbolizing desolation and despair during the drought.

questions.question: What action do the nobles of Judah take in Jeremiah 14:3 in their search for water?
options: They send their little ones to the waters and pits but find none
They send priests to pray for rain
They dig new wells
They bring offerings to the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They send their little ones to the waters and pits but find none
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:3 describes nobles sending children to fetch water, but they return ashamed and empty-handed, highlighting the severity of the drought.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14:6, the wild asses are described as snuffing up the wind like dragons. What is the significance of this simile in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It emphasizes their desperate thirst and blindness due to lack of grass
It indicates their strength and fierceness
It symbolizes divine protection over animals
It suggests their ability to fly
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes their desperate thirst and blindness due to lack of grass
questions.explanation: The simile in Jeremiah 14:6 uses the imagery of dragons, creatures associated with desolation, to illustrate the wild asses’ suffering from famine and drought, emphasizing desperation and failing eyesight.

questions.question: Jeremiah’s prayer in verse 7 acknowledges their sinfulness but pleads for God’s intervention 'for thy name's sake.' What theological theme does this reveal?
options: God’s covenantal faithfulness despite Israel's sin
The inevitability of divine punishment
Human self-righteousness
The irrelevance of prayer in judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenantal faithfulness despite Israel's sin
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:7 shows the tension between Israel's guilt and the hope that God will act to uphold His own name and covenant, a recurrent theme throughout Scripture.

questions.question: What is the nature of the complaint against the prophets in Jeremiah 14:14?
options: They prophesy lies and false visions in God's name
They preach repentance faithfully
They urge the people to prepare for war
They support the Babylonian invasion
questions.correctAnswer: They prophesy lies and false visions in God's name
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:14 explicitly states that the prophets speak falsehoods, claiming divine authority without God's commission, representing false prophecy and deception.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 14:15, what will be the fate of the false prophets who deny the coming sword and famine?
options: They will be consumed by sword and famine themselves
They will be rewarded with peace
They will lead the people to victory
They will be exiled to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They will be consumed by sword and famine themselves
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:15 warns that false prophets will not escape the judgment they deny, highlighting divine justice and accountability.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14:16, what is the tragic consequence for the people who heed the false prophets?
options: They will be cast out in Jerusalem's streets and left unburied
They will be taken captive to Egypt
They will prosper as a nation
They will be protected from famine
questions.correctAnswer: They will be cast out in Jerusalem's streets and left unburied
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:16 portrays the severe social breakdown and divine wrath leaving victims unburied, symbolizing utter disgrace and calamity.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in Jeremiah 14:17 where Jeremiah says his eyes shall run down with tears night and day?
options: Hyperbole to express deep sorrow
Metaphor for divine justice
Simile comparing tears to rivers
Allegory of national restoration
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole to express deep sorrow
questions.explanation: The phrase in Jeremiah 14:17 uses hyperbole to vividly express Jeremiah’s profound grief over the brokenness of his people.

questions.question: Jeremiah 14:18 mentions both slain by the sword and those sick with famine. How does this duality contribute to the overall theme of the chapter?
options: It shows the comprehensive judgment against Judah by war and drought
It contrasts physical and spiritual destruction
It predicts a future restoration
It implies divine abandonment
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the comprehensive judgment against Judah by war and drought
questions.explanation: The verse juxtaposes death by violence and death by hunger, portraying the total devastation that Judah suffers, emphasizing the severity of divine judgment.

questions.question: True or False: According to Jeremiah 14:11, God instructs Jeremiah to continue praying for the people’s good despite their sins.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:11 clearly states that the LORD told Jeremiah not to pray for the people’s good because of their persistent sin.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14:19, what question does Jeremiah ask that reflects a deep theological struggle?
options: Has God utterly rejected Judah and why is there no healing?
Will God send a new prophet to save them?
Is Babylon stronger than Israel?
Why do the nations worship false gods?
questions.correctAnswer: Has God utterly rejected Judah and why is there no healing?
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:19 expresses lament and confusion over apparent divine rejection despite Israel’s hope for peace and healing.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 14:22 emphasize the uniqueness of the LORD compared to Gentile 'vanities'?
options: By affirming that only the LORD can cause rain and showers
By stating that Gentile gods are more powerful
By predicting the end of all gods
By denying the need for rain
questions.correctAnswer: By affirming that only the LORD can cause rain and showers
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:22 contrasts impotent Gentile idols with the LORD’s sovereign control over nature, reinforcing monotheistic worship.

questions.question: Jeremiah 14:10 uses the phrase 'Thus have they loved to wander.' What does this imply about the people's spiritual condition?
options: They have persistently turned away from God
They have remained faithful to the covenant
They have been wandering in the wilderness physically
They have sought foreign alliances
questions.correctAnswer: They have persistently turned away from God
questions.explanation: The phrase implies willful disobedience and spiritual unfaithfulness, leading to God’s judgment as described in Jeremiah 14:10.

questions.question: What is the significance of the imagery of 'covering their heads' by the plowmen and nobles in Jeremiah 14:4 and 14:3?
options: It symbolizes shame and mourning in ancient Near Eastern culture
It indicates preparation for battle
It represents joy and celebration
It is a ritual cleansing practice
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes shame and mourning in ancient Near Eastern culture
questions.explanation: Covering the head was a common sign of grief and shame, as shown in these verses during the drought and famine context.

questions.question: Jeremiah 14:12 declares that God will not accept the people's fasting or offerings. What does this reveal about the relationship between ritual and righteousness?
options: Ritual acts are insufficient without genuine repentance
Ritual acts guarantee divine favor
Offerings can replace obedience
Fasting is the ultimate form of worship
questions.correctAnswer: Ritual acts are insufficient without genuine repentance
questions.explanation: The verse shows that God rejects empty rituals when the people persist in sin, emphasizing the need for authentic repentance.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given in Jeremiah 14 for the drought and famine in Judah?
options: Because the ground is chapt and there was no rain
Because of a natural disaster
Because of war with neighboring nations
Because of a divine test of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Because the ground is chapt and there was no rain
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:4 states that the drought is due to the ground being chapt because there was no rain. This reflects God’s judgment for sin, consistent with Deuteronomy 28:23-24 and James 5:17-18 where droughts come as consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14, how does the LORD describe the people's wandering and sinfulness?
options: They have loved to wander and not refrained their feet
They have repented and returned to God
They have been faithful servants
They have sought wisdom from the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They have loved to wander and not refrained their feet
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:10 describes the people's persistent rebellion and refusal to turn back to God. This aligns with the biblical theme of human sinfulness and the need for repentance as seen in Isaiah 53:6 and Romans 3:23.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 14, why will God not accept the people's fasting and offerings?
options: Because they have sinned and God will consume them by sword, famine, and pestilence
Because their offerings were not burnt properly
Because they fasted on the wrong days
Because they did not pray loudly enough
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have sinned and God will consume them by sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:12 explains that God will not hear the people's cries or accept their offerings because of their persistent sin, reflecting God's holiness and justice (cf. Isaiah 1:11-17; Amos 5:21-24; Hebrews 10:26-27).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah say about the false prophets in Jeremiah 14?
options: They prophesy lies in God's name without His command
They faithfully proclaim God's word
They lead the people to repentance
They predict the Messiah accurately
questions.correctAnswer: They prophesy lies in God's name without His command
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:14 reveals that the false prophets speak deceitfully, claiming God's authority without His sending. This warns against false teaching, consistent with Deuteronomy 18:20-22 and 2 Peter 2:1.

questions.question: What consequence does Jeremiah 14 say will come upon the false prophets who claim no sword or famine will come?
options: They will be consumed by sword and famine
They will be exalted by the people
They will be ignored
They will be given riches
questions.correctAnswer: They will be consumed by sword and famine
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:15 declares that false prophets who deny God's judgment will themselves be destroyed by the very calamities they deny, reflecting God's justice on false teachers (cf. Ezekiel 13:9; Matthew 7:15-20).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14, how is the LORD portrayed in relation to His people’s sin and suffering?
options: A just judge who remembers iniquity but also a compassionate God who is the hope of Israel
An indifferent observer
A distant deity unconcerned with human affairs
A wrathful god without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: A just judge who remembers iniquity but also a compassionate God who is the hope of Israel
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:7-10 and 14:8-9 show God’s justice in punishing sin but also His role as Savior and hope, consistent with Exodus 34:6-7 and Psalm 103:8-12, revealing the balance of God's holiness and mercy.

questions.question: What is the plea of Jeremiah and the people regarding God's covenant in Jeremiah 14?
options: Do not break your covenant with us for your name's sake
Forget us because of our sins
Destroy us completely
Ignore our prayers
questions.correctAnswer: Do not break your covenant with us for your name's sake
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:21 contains a plea to God not to abandon His covenant, emphasizing God's faithfulness and the importance of His promises (cf. Genesis 9:16; 2 Corinthians 1:20).

questions.question: What natural elements are questioned in Jeremiah 14 as to their ability to provide rain?
options: Vanities of the Gentiles and the heavens
Mountains and rivers
Stars and moon
Trees and animals
questions.correctAnswer: Vanities of the Gentiles and the heavens
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:22 asks rhetorically if idols ('vanities') or the heavens can cause rain, affirming the LORD as the true God who controls nature, consistent with Psalm 135:7 and Matthew 5:45.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah describe the condition of Jerusalem’s gates and the people's reaction to the drought?
options: The gates languish and are black unto the ground; people are ashamed and cover their heads
The gates are strong and people rejoice
The gates are open and people worship idols
The gates are fortified but people are indifferent
questions.correctAnswer: The gates languish and are black unto the ground; people are ashamed and cover their heads
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:2-3 describes Judah’s mourning with gates languishing and people ashamed, symbolizing national calamity and repentance as seen in Lamentations 1:8 and Ezekiel 7:18.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Jeremiah 14 to depict the suffering of animals due to the drought?
options: The hind calves in the field and forsakes it; wild asses stand in high places snuffing the wind
Animals gather by rivers to drink abundantly
Animals are unaffected and roam freely
Animals build shelters to protect themselves
questions.correctAnswer: The hind calves in the field and forsakes it; wild asses stand in high places snuffing the wind
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:5-6 uses vivid imagery of animals suffering from lack of grass and water, illustrating the severity of the drought and God's judgment, similar to Habakkuk 3:17 and Job 30:1-4.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah express about the people’s expectation for peace and healing in Jeremiah 14?
options: They looked for peace, but there was no good; for healing, but behold trouble
They experienced immediate peace and healing
They abandoned hope entirely
They trusted in foreign alliances for peace
questions.correctAnswer: They looked for peace, but there was no good; for healing, but behold trouble
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:19 records a lament that despite seeking peace and healing, only trouble remains, reflecting the consequences of sin and God's discipline, consistent with Psalm 38:3-8 and Isaiah 57:20-21.

questions.question: What does God command Jeremiah regarding prayer for the people in Jeremiah 14?
options: Pray not for their good
Pray earnestly for their deliverance
Pray only for the king
Pray in secret only
questions.correctAnswer: Pray not for their good
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:11 reveals God's command to Jeremiah not to pray for the people’s welfare due to their persistent rebellion, underscoring God's righteous judgment (cf. Ezekiel 14:14; Romans 1:24).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 14, what does Jeremiah say the prophet's eyes should do in response to the people's suffering?
options: Run down with tears night and day
Be closed to avoid sorrow
Look away with indifference
Be filled with anger
questions.correctAnswer: Run down with tears night and day
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:17 commands Jeremiah to weep continually for the brokenness of the people, demonstrating prophetic compassion as seen in Ezekiel 9:4 and John 11:35.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Jeremiah 14 for the people being cast out in the streets of Jerusalem without burial for their dead?
options: Because of the famine and sword and their wickedness
Because of an epidemic unrelated to sin
Because of foreign invasion only
Because the priests commanded it
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the famine and sword and their wickedness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:16 explains that famine, sword, and their own wickedness cause the people to be left unburied, highlighting the severity of divine judgment (cf. 2 Kings 21:16; Ezekiel 33:27).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah describe the condition of the prophet and priest in the land during the calamity?
options: They go about into a land they know not
They lead the people in worship
They are protected in Jerusalem
They receive visions of hope
questions.correctAnswer: They go about into a land they know not
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 14:18 depicts the prophet and priest as disoriented and wandering, symbolizing the spiritual confusion and judgment upon religious leaders, paralleling Ezekiel 34:2-4 and Matthew 23:27-28.
